item.description: Anyone have a good real-world, real-data example of Simpson's paradox, from a paper with open data?

item.title: #en @ 1460356793092083712
item.description: Our bigger point is simply that that #lakehouse systems based on open data formats (Delta Lake) are now competitive with the best data warehouses, so there's no need to lock away part of your data just to do DW workloads. Even Snowflake's results on their cheapest tier show this.

item.title: #en @ 1460331497072832516
item.description:
The killer app of Web3 isn't an app: it's the new way apps will be built and interact via open data.

item.title: #en @ 1459569309009776648
item.description: Lesson 3: I was only able to do this analysis because the data and materials were open. Open data are great. But (to use a @siminevazire analogy) transparency only opens the hood. You still need to see what the engine looks like.

item.title: #en @ 1459569295948759041
item.description: Second, the authors also collected people's estimates of the temperature ("What do you think the temperature is outside right now?"). This was not reported in the paper, but it is in the open data + materials. This is a plausible alternative DV.
